blog.description: Hi! I'm a French shipper, fanfiction writer and reader and aspiring novelist! I'm a Gryffindor who supports House Stark and my Queen in the North until the end of the world, and a huge fan of SPN, Teen Wolf, Sherlock,  Harry Potter, GoT, Good Omens and lots of others! 💜💙💚

summary: Tyrion is the real danger for the Six Kingdoms
title: Tyrion is the real danger for the Six Kingdoms
body:
I’ve just realised something about Tyrion – and mind you, it doesn’t look good at all.

I was revolted (and I still am) by Tyrion’s attitude in the last episodes, especially the fact that he denounced Varys, which led to his inevitable demise, even though Tyrion knew that Varys was right, that Daenerys was dangerous and that she would burn King’s Landing to the ground.

I was also angry at him for basically doing nothing in the last episode. He acted like a drama queen by throwing his badge away and then encouraged Jon to kill Dany, while he could have kept the badge and done something. Tried to kill Dany himself. Hatched a plan. Actively conspired with Jon. Or even try to kill Dany and, if he failed, make Jon look like Dany’s most loyal supporter so that Dany would not suspect a thing – which is a dumb plan but at least Tyrion would have done something. 

But then I thought about something.

Tyrion purposefully sent Jon to his own death

At this point, Jon was the only candidate for the Throne. Varys and Tyrion had talked about it a lot, and I think we can assume that Jon was the only option left. It was maybe not the best option, because Jon being King might have sparked a war, but it was still better than several Lords fighting each other in order to become King. Having a candidate with a good claim and a good reputation was the best option available,  and, I daresay, the only option. 

Logically, Tyrion should have hatched a plan or something, prepared some ground for Daenerys’ fall and for Jon’s reign. But no – he just quit and then told Jon that he had to kill Dany. (Which, for the record, I don’t disagree with. I think Dany needed to die. What I dislike is the fact that Tyrion did nothing but sit on his ass and expect other people to do the job.)

Except that Tyrion knows full well what the punishment for kingslaying is, no matter how cruel the assassinated monarch was. When sending Jon to kill Daenerys, he had to know that Jon would not live long after that. Granted, most Kingdoms would probably not care at all, but the Unsullied and the Dothraki would care, and a Kingslayer was unlikely to become King anyway. 

Moreover, Tyrion was in jail and did not have a way to know what had happened in detail - and yet, he spends time planning on a replacement for Jon. He does not even try to argue that yes, Jon killed Dany but it was justified and the only thing to do, and he happily fails to mention his own role in the murder - to instead walk away unpunished. After Jon killed Daenerys, Tyrion just… moved on and schemed with another King in mind. So no, you cannot tell me that Tyrion did not know that Jon’s actions would likely have him killed. He knew. 

And the worst thing is that Tyrion knew and never tried to think of another option. Not a single second. He was very confident of what he was doing. 

Granted, Tyrion could not know he would survive. But he knew, for sure, that Jon would not, and even if he did he would no longer be a candidate for the Throne.

So Tyrion just sent the only candidate they had for the Throne to his own death and he was aware of it.

And, yeah, OK, bad writing and everything, but the Tyrion scene was not important in itself. Tyrion already had loads of scenes and of talking in this episode. Jon could have talked with Arya - who would have given him the same advice, and who would have helped him - or with Davos - who just did nothing in Season 8 except wanting to kill a woman who only appeared in Episode 2. So I am not sure we can say that it is only a case of bad writing, and that is what makes me so uncomfortable with Tyrion.

So what was he thinking? I don’t know. We’ll never know. But I’m looking at the results.

Tyrion built his own tyrannical government 

We know that Tyrion managed to manipulate the people who were at the Dragonpit meeting so that they did what he wanted. I say “manipulation”, because that’s exactly what it is. Whether it was a good thing or not is up for debate, but he did that. He charmed his way into getting people to do what he wanted. He sweet-talked them into listening to him. Tyrion Silver-Tongue has a talent for that. 

And because of that, we have a monarchy once again, with a monarch that Tyrion chose personnally, and Tyrion ends up being the Hand of the King (even though he proved that he was a shitty Hand) - which is supposed to be his punishment even though it is the thing he always dreamt of being. 

And then - look at the Council. He names his best mate Master of Coin even though Bronn knows nothing about money and even though the Crown, in all likelihood, has a giant debt to repay to the Iron Bank. Mind you, giving Bronn Highgarden in order not to be killed does not mean making him Lord Paramount of the Reach (you can transfer this title to whatever Lord in the Reach that is competent enough) and does not mean making him Treasurer in Chief of the realm either. And I am sure that there were other Lords that were more competent as well.

The others are not so bad, but there’s still a problem with them anyway. Sam is sweet and full of good ideas, but he is not a Maester. At this point, he probably had no idea how to tend to people, even though most of the inhabitants of King’s Landing need medical help. Sam doesn’t know anything else either - administration, for example. Having him as one of Bran’s advisors is not a bad idea in itself, but the Grand Maester should have been someone else. 

Now, as much as I love Brienne and Davos, the fact that they are in the Small Council is troubling in itself. They are competent, it’s a fact, but we can also see that Tyrion chose only his friends to be in the Small Council. This is why the last seats are empty: because he only chose friends of his. Which reveals, too, that the kingdoms are not at all represented in the Council. Sam, Davos, Brienne can hardly act as representatives of their respective kingdoms - for one, they haven’t been there for a long time, and it is unlikely that anyone in the Reach or in the Stormlands would appeal to them if need be. I do not know much about politics, but it would have made sense to have a Dornish representative in the Council, as well as someone from the Iron Islands, maybe as a Master of Ships (after all, both kingdoms want independence, so tight relationships with them might ensure peace). Someone from the Riverlands would make sense as well, given that Lannisters and Tullys were at war, and maybe someone from the Vale (I mean, as the Vale are allied with the North, it would make sense to try and have good relationships with them)?

But no, Tyrion chose his friends. Of course, we might argue that it was Bran who chose them, but I doubt so. Bran only has a relationship with Sam. Bronn, Brienne and Davos are strangers to him. So, I think they really were Tyrion’s choice - and Tyrion chose everything, even who should be King. If Bran chose them, he would have used his powers to know who was the most competent person in the realm. So the one in power is not Bran; it’s actually Tyrion.

Then, of course, Tyrion’s reasoning is that Bran would be a good King because he’s neutral and would only do what is necessary for the realm - except that, of course, a neutral king who feels nothing is not a good idea. An emotionless king also means a king who does not feel pity or compassion. An emotionless king means a king who would plan everything according to a higher purpose, which would likely lead to neglecting everything that has nothing to do with the Great Purpose that only him could see - for example, the smallfolk. What is a few starved people compared to ensuring peace? 

So why would Tyrion choose Bran at all? My opinion is that, since Bran knows everything, Tyrion thinks he is the best safety system that could ever be. If the Small Council were to make a bad decision, Bran would know it and would stop it. If a rebellion or a war was arising, Bran would know it in time so that they be able to prepare and crush it. And he would not do it out of personal feelings, but because it is the truth, so people just have to nod. 

Tyrion did not choose a king who would reign; he choose an insurance policy. 

Basically, the Council just has to make choices and Bran says “yes” or “no”. This is basically what happens in the last episode: Bran leaves, the Council makes decisions. Because this is the thing with a King who feels nothing at all: most things are inconsequential and are not important in the great scheme of things. 

So Tyrion would make decisions, and expect Bran to tell him if his choices are bad. That’s all.

Of course, it’s a convenient system. People only have to do what the King tells them to do. Bran knows better after all, he is a godlike entity, isn’t he? We fall into a pattern of blind obedience. And Bran knows everything, which is just creepy and reminds me of the Patriot’s Act if you want my opinion. And finally – look at what Tyrion is doing in the final episode, chanting “All hail Bran the Broken” and everything. 

Blind obedience. Capacity to spy on everyone. Institutionalised devotion. Government composed of close friends, not competent people. 

Yeah, it makes me feel really uneasy. 

Actually, Tyrion acts just like Daenerys

It makes me even more uneasy when we know that Tyrion fell into that trap before with Daenerys (except that “capacity to spy on everyone” was replaced with “capacity to kill everyone”). 

This is why I am wary of Tyrion. He got rid of Jon, and I have difficulty believing that it was not intentional. And now, he’s setting up a government that looks pretty much tyrannical. 

The thing is, Tyrion acts very much like Dany, and that’s why I believe he loved her, as he told Jon. 

Tyrion also confesses that he hasn’t had sex in a while, ever since Shae. And this is the thing. He has not been interested by women ever since Shae - or even since Daenerys. The two event pretty much occur at the same time, actually. And remember Tyrion’s face during Jon and Dany’s boatbang? Yeah. It was jealousy.

The thing was Tyrion admired Dany a lot. He agreed with almost everything she did, except for burning people. I think that’s where Tyrion draws the line: massacring civilians for the sake of it.

Tyrion denounced Varys for trying to kill Daenerys and for generally opposing her, while knowing full well that she would burn King’s Landing to the ground. Tyrion tries to prevent that from happening by sending Jaime to Cersei, but actually, if he really wanted to prevent it, the real solution was to kill Dany or support Jon’s claim, or at least let Varys do his business. Tyrion could just turn a blind eye and let things happen. No one would have resented him.

The thing is that Tyrion still wanted to be by Dany’s side. His aim was to prevent her from burning King’s Landing, but he knew, he had to know, that she would burn other cities. That it would not be the end of it. But even though he betrayed her, he did not ensure that she would never hurt anyone. For me, it shows that he was still willing to follow her. Granted, he would have tried, again and again, to prevent her from burning citizens, but he was still willing to be by her side. He knew that a massacre was coming and he still loved Daenerys. She had committed massacres already and he still supported her. 

In the last episode, he mentions that “she killed the bad guys and we cheered her for it”, but he never mentions how the bad guys might… not actually be bad guys, after all (if we think about the innocent masters or the Khals, who weren’t killed because of their way of life but because she wanted to take their place). He never mentions that her way of killing people was cruel even from the start. He agreed with it up until she began burning people he knew and loved. 

In the same way, he did not think she should just calm down and stop threatening people, he thought people should stop provoking her. He already knew what was likely to happen if people (let’s say, Sansa) kept doing so. He was uneasy with it. But he still supported Daenerys.

And why, would you say? Why would he draw the limit at “burning civilians” but not for the rest? Because Tyrion thought she was doing great with the rest. And we see that in his government, because it mimicks Daenerys’.

His government is composed of close friends that would not oppose him, or so he thinks; and it relies heavily on obedience. The economy is not important in the government; no one takes military decisions but the authority in place (Dany or Bran or Tyrion); a lot of attention is given to the personal guard, but not to the rest. No one is there to represent the law. Most locals or nobles are not represented. People who have done nothing to deserve their titles get high authority. And, even though he has seen first hand what happens when someone is given way too much authority, he still believes in a strong central government with no room for independence, just like Dany - because he has the Bran safety stamp, so no problem.

 Tyrion tries to impose a kind of personality cult around Bran that looks like the one around Dany - Bran is magical so he knows better; Bran’s decisions are to be met with blind agreement because, you know, he’s omniscient. Tyrion’s government relies heavily on magical powers that actually put civilians at great risk. Tyrion’s choice as king would most likely focus on the Great Scheme of Things and The Higher Purpose, just like Dany did - even if there is a high risk that things go downhill for the common people, just like with Dany. 

And Tyrion suffers from the same ambition than Dany. Tyrion loves power, we know that. And he seeks glory as well, thinking himself to be super important in the story when he’s not. And he’s just as self-righteous as Dany was. If you look at his time as Joffrey’s Hand, his decisions were to be respected and he was to have power because he was the one to deserve it, and because he knows better. (You know, he drinks and he knows things.) His choice of Bran as King is to be respected because he knows things and because he’s wise and whatever. He gets rid of Jon because “it’s the only thing to do, there’s no other choice” – and then he plots for another king that fits his personal criteria, which coincidentally happen to be a replica of Daenerys’ criteria. You know what it reminds me of? “You are not fit to rule. But I am.” You are not fit to make decisions and to choose a King, but I am.

This is why Tyrion was so blind to Dany’s cruelty, and why it became different for him when she burnt people he knew: because in the end, he would have done things like her. Tyrion has learnt nothing, even though he pretends he had. He keeps committing the same mistakes over and over again.

Of course, you would say, “But Bran knows everything and if he thought that Tyrion was a bad person he would not have taken the Throne or taken Tyrion as Hand” and, actually, I think that Bran had no way of knowing that. Bran sees things, he does not feel them. He does not read people’s minds. He does not know that Tyrion shares similarities with Dany.

Because yes, he does. 

The thing is that, just like Dany, I don’t think he is conscious of it. I don’t think he coldly thought “Let’s have Jon killed along with Dany, two birds with one stone, I need to get rid of Jon”. He did send him to his likely death, and was certain that he would prevent Jon from being King, but I don’t think it was the result of a coldblooded scheme to get rid of Jon. I think that Tyrion is like Dany in this respect. He thought it was necessary. He justified it by telling it was the only thing left to do. And after all, he ensured that Jon did not die, and Jon didn’t want that Throne anyway, did he? So, no harm done. 

I am sure this is Tyrion’s reasoning. He chooses Bran because he thinks it’s the best choice. He handles his government in a certain way because he’s certain that this is the best thing to do. Because just like Daenerys, he’s proud and he thinks he’s always right. And just like Daenerys, he has a way to seduce people into, if not following him, at least listening to him. 

And if people agree with him then he’s doing things right, isn’t he?

Conclusion - Tyrion has the potential to be your everyday villain, just like Dany

I don’t think Tyrion was smiling in a satisfied, evil way and rubbing his hands together because everything went according to plan. He is exactly the type of villain that Dany was. The type that people (both in the show and in the audience) can like, the type that is relatable. The type that does not do bad things because he’s evil but because he thinks it’s the only way and because it’s the right thing to do. The type that does not realise that he’s doing bad things; and when he does, he thinks he has to do so nevertheless for “the greater good”. He is just like Dany. 

Of course, Tyrion will not end up burning cities to the ground. No, I see him making decisions that might have disastrous consequences - starvation, revolts, wars, things like that. If we’re lucky, maybe Bran will be able to prevent it from happening. I think maybe Tyrion will not even commit such mistakes. 

But he has the potential to commit them, because he makes horrible decisions that he feels are justified (like sending Jon to his own death), because he always turns things to his own advantage, because he likes power, because he reproduces a tyrannical system, because he does not realise it, because he has fallen in the same trap than Dany - that is, thinking that he is the hero. 

And the worst thing is that, if you want my opinion, D&D did not realise what they might have done with Tyrion’s character. They were blind to Dany’s cruelties in the past. She was their heroine up until GRRM said “hell no, she’s the bad one”. D&D reproduced the same system all over again without even seeing what they did. 

Of course, this is only my interpretation (and it might be heavily influenced by my own dislike of Tyrion after Season 8, or by the awful writing). I am open to any comment and/or constructive criticism. But I’m pretty sure that Tyrion is much more dangerous than we thought.

In the last episode, he mentions that “she killed the bad guys and we cheered her for it”, but he never mentions how the bad guys might… not actually be bad guys, after all (if we think about the innocent masters or the Khals, who weren’t killed because of their way of life but because she wanted to take their place). He never mentions that her way of killing people was cruel even from the start. He agreed with it up until she began burning people he knew and loved. 

In the same way, he did not think she should just calm down and stop threatening people, he thought people should stop provoking her. He already knew what was likely to happen if people (let’s say, Sansa) kept doing so. He was uneasy with it. But he still supported Daenerys.

And why, would you say? Why would he draw the limit at “burning civilians” but not for the rest? Because Tyrion thought she was doing great with the rest. And we see that in his government, because it mimicks Daenerys’.

His government is composed of close friends that would not oppose him, or so he thinks; and it relies heavily on obedience. The economy is not important in the government; no one takes military decisions but the authority in place (Dany or Bran or Tyrion); a lot of attention is given to the personal guard, but not to the rest. No one is there to represent the law. Most locals or nobles are not represented. People who have done nothing to deserve their titles get high authority. And, even though he has seen first hand what happens when someone is given way too much authority, he still believes in a strong central government with no room for independence, just like Dany - because he has the Bran safety stamp, so no problem.

 Tyrion tries to impose a kind of personality cult around Bran that looks like the one around Dany - Bran is magical so he knows better; Bran’s decisions are to be met with blind agreement because, you know, he’s omniscient. Tyrion’s government relies heavily on magical powers that actually put civilians at great risk. Tyrion’s choice as king would most likely focus on the Great Scheme of Things and The Higher Purpose, just like Dany did - even if there is a high risk that things go downhill for the common people, just like with Dany. 

And Tyrion suffers from the same ambition than Dany. Tyrion loves power, we know that. And he seeks glory as well, thinking himself to be super important in the story when he’s not. And he’s just as self-righteous as Dany was. If you look at his time as Joffrey’s Hand, his decisions were to be respected and he was to have power because he was the one to deserve it, and because he knows better. (You know, he drinks and he knows things.) His choice of Bran as King is to be respected because he knows things and because he’s wise and whatever. He gets rid of Jon because “it’s the only thing to do, there’s no other choice” – and then he plots for another king that fits his personal criteria, which coincidentally happen to be a replica of Daenerys’ criteria. You know what it reminds me of? “You are not fit to rule. But I am.” You are not fit to make decisions and to choose a King, but I am.

This is why Tyrion was so blind to Dany’s cruelty, and why it became different for him when she burnt people he knew: because in the end, he would have done things like her. Tyrion has learnt nothing, even though he pretends he had. He keeps committing the same mistakes over and over again.

Of course, you would say, “But Bran knows everything and if he thought that Tyrion was a bad person he would not have taken the Throne or taken Tyrion as Hand” and, actually, I think that Bran had no way of knowing that. Bran sees things, he does not feel them. He does not read people’s minds. He does not know that Tyrion shares similarities with Dany.

Because yes, he does. 

The thing is that, just like Dany, I don’t think he is conscious of it. I don’t think he coldly thought “Let’s have Jon killed along with Dany, two birds with one stone, I need to get rid of Jon”. He did send him to his likely death, and was certain that he would prevent Jon from being King, but I don’t think it was the result of a coldblooded scheme to get rid of Jon. I think that Tyrion is like Dany in this respect. He thought it was necessary. He justified it by telling it was the only thing left to do. And after all, he ensured that Jon did not die, and Jon didn’t want that Throne anyway, did he? So, no harm done. 

I am sure this is Tyrion’s reasoning. He chooses Bran because he thinks it’s the best choice. He handles his government in a certain way because he’s certain that this is the best thing to do. Because just like Daenerys, he’s proud and he thinks he’s always right. And just like Daenerys, he has a way to seduce people into, if not following him, at least listening to him. 

And if people agree with him then he’s doing things right, isn’t he?

Conclusion - Tyrion has the potential to be your everyday villain, just like Dany

I don’t think Tyrion was smiling in a satisfied, evil way and rubbing his hands together because everything went according to plan. He is exactly the type of villain that Dany was. The type that people (both in the show and in the audience) can like, the type that is relatable. The type that does not do bad things because he’s evil but because he thinks it’s the only way and because it’s the right thing to do. The type that does not realise that he’s doing bad things; and when he does, he thinks he has to do so nevertheless for “the greater good”. He is just like Dany. 

Of course, Tyrion will not end up burning cities to the ground. No, I see him making decisions that might have disastrous consequences - starvation, revolts, wars, things like that. If we’re lucky, maybe Bran will be able to prevent it from happening. I think maybe Tyrion will not even commit such mistakes. 

But he has the potential to commit them, because he makes horrible decisions that he feels are justified (like sending Jon to his own death), because he always turns things to his own advantage, because he likes power, because he reproduces a tyrannical system, because he does not realise it, because he has fallen in the same trap than Dany - that is, thinking that he is the hero. 

And the worst thing is that, if you want my opinion, D&D did not realise what they might have done with Tyrion’s character. They were blind to Dany’s cruelties in the past. She was their heroine up until GRRM said “hell no, she’s the bad one”. D&D reproduced the same system all over again without even seeing what they did. 

Of course, this is only my interpretation (and it might be heavily influenced by my own dislike of Tyrion after Season 8, or by the awful writing). I am open to any comment and/or constructive criticism. But I’m pretty sure that Tyrion is much more dangerous than we thought.

trail.content_raw:
I’ve just realised something about Tyrion – and mind you, it doesn’t look good at all.

I was revolted (and I still am) by Tyrion’s attitude in the last episodes, especially the fact that he denounced Varys, which led to his inevitable demise, even though Tyrion knew that Varys was right, that Daenerys was dangerous and that she would burn King’s Landing to the ground.

I was also angry at him for basically doing nothing in the last episode. He acted like a drama queen by throwing his badge away and then encouraged Jon to kill Dany, while he could have kept the badge and done something. Tried to kill Dany himself. Hatched a plan. Actively conspired with Jon. Or even try to kill Dany and, if he failed, make Jon look like Dany’s most loyal supporter so that Dany would not suspect a thing – which is a dumb plan but at least Tyrion would have done something. 

But then I thought about something.

[[MORE]]

Tyrion purposefully sent Jon to his own death

At this point, Jon was the only candidate for the Throne. Varys and Tyrion had talked about it a lot, and I think we can assume that Jon was the only option left. It was maybe not the best option, because Jon being King might have sparked a war, but it was still better than several Lords fighting each other in order to become King. Having a candidate with a good claim and a good reputation was the best option available,  and, I daresay, the only option. 

Logically, Tyrion should have hatched a plan or something, prepared some ground for Daenerys’ fall and for Jon’s reign. But no – he just quit and then told Jon that he had to kill Dany. (Which, for the record, I don’t disagree with. I think Dany needed to die. What I dislike is the fact that Tyrion did nothing but sit on his ass and expect other people to do the job.)

Except that Tyrion knows full well what the punishment for kingslaying is, no matter how cruel the assassinated monarch was. When sending Jon to kill Daenerys, he had to know that Jon would not live long after that. Granted, most Kingdoms would probably not care at all, but the Unsullied and the Dothraki would care, and a Kingslayer was unlikely to become King anyway. 

Moreover, Tyrion was in jail and did not have a way to know what had happened in detail - and yet, he spends time planning on a replacement for Jon. He does not even try to argue that yes, Jon killed Dany but it was justified and the only thing to do, and he happily fails to mention his own role in the murder - to instead walk away unpunished. After Jon killed Daenerys, Tyrion just… moved on and schemed with another King in mind. So no, you cannot tell me that Tyrion did not know that Jon’s actions would likely have him killed. He knew. 

And the worst thing is that Tyrion knew and never tried to think of another option. Not a single second. He was very confident of what he was doing. 

Granted, Tyrion could not know he would survive. But he knew, for sure, that Jon would not, and even if he did he would no longer be a candidate for the Throne.

So Tyrion just sent the only candidate they had for the Throne to his own death and he was aware of it.

And, yeah, OK, bad writing and everything, but the Tyrion scene was not important in itself. Tyrion already had loads of scenes and of talking in this episode. Jon could have talked with Arya - who would have given him the same advice, and who would have helped him - or with Davos - who just did nothing in Season 8 except wanting to kill a woman who only appeared in Episode 2. So I am not sure we can say that it is only a case of bad writing, and that is what makes me so uncomfortable with Tyrion.

So what was he thinking? I don’t know. We’ll never know. But I’m looking at the results.

Tyrion built his own tyrannical government 

We know that Tyrion managed to manipulate the people who were at the Dragonpit meeting so that they did what he wanted. I say “manipulation”, because that’s exactly what it is. Whether it was a good thing or not is up for debate, but he did that. He charmed his way into getting people to do what he wanted. He sweet-talked them into listening to him. Tyrion Silver-Tongue has a talent for that. 

And because of that, we have a monarchy once again, with a monarch that Tyrion chose personnally, and Tyrion ends up being the Hand of the King (even though he proved that he was a shitty Hand) - which is supposed to be his punishment even though it is the thing he always dreamt of being. 

And then - look at the Council. He names his best mate Master of Coin even though Bronn knows nothing about money and even though the Crown, in all likelihood, has a giant debt to repay to the Iron Bank. Mind you, giving Bronn Highgarden in order not to be killed does not mean making him Lord Paramount of the Reach (you can transfer this title to whatever Lord in the Reach that is competent enough) and does not mean making him Treasurer in Chief of the realm either. And I am sure that there were other Lords that were more competent as well.

The others are not so bad, but there’s still a problem with them anyway. Sam is sweet and full of good ideas, but he is not a Maester. At this point, he probably had no idea how to tend to people, even though most of the inhabitants of King’s Landing need medical help. Sam doesn’t know anything else either - administration, for example. Having him as one of Bran’s advisors is not a bad idea in itself, but the Grand Maester should have been someone else. 

Now, as much as I love Brienne and Davos, the fact that they are in the Small Council is troubling in itself. They are competent, it’s a fact, but we can also see that Tyrion chose only his friends to be in the Small Council. This is why the last seats are empty: because he only chose friends of his. Which reveals, too, that the kingdoms are not at all represented in the Council. Sam, Davos, Brienne can hardly act as representatives of their respective kingdoms - for one, they haven’t been there for a long time, and it is unlikely that anyone in the Reach or in the Stormlands would appeal to them if need be. I do not know much about politics, but it would have made sense to have a Dornish representative in the Council, as well as someone from the Iron Islands, maybe as a Master of Ships (after all, both kingdoms want independence, so tight relationships with them might ensure peace). Someone from the Riverlands would make sense as well, given that Lannisters and Tullys were at war, and maybe someone from the Vale (I mean, as the Vale are allied with the North, it would make sense to try and have good relationships with them)?

But no, Tyrion chose his friends. Of course, we might argue that it was Bran who chose them, but I doubt so. Bran only has a relationship with Sam. Bronn, Brienne and Davos are strangers to him. So, I think they really were Tyrion’s choice - and Tyrion chose everything, even who should be King. If Bran chose them, he would have used his powers to know who was the most competent person in the realm. So the one in power is not Bran; it’s actually Tyrion.

Then, of course, Tyrion’s reasoning is that Bran would be a good King because he’s neutral and would only do what is necessary for the realm - except that, of course, a neutral king who feels nothing is not a good idea. An emotionless king also means a king who does not feel pity or compassion. An emotionless king means a king who would plan everything according to a higher purpose, which would likely lead to neglecting everything that has nothing to do with the Great Purpose that only him could see - for example, the smallfolk. What is a few starved people compared to ensuring peace? 

So why would Tyrion choose Bran at all? My opinion is that, since Bran knows everything, Tyrion thinks he is the best safety system that could ever be. If the Small Council were to make a bad decision, Bran would know it and would stop it. If a rebellion or a war was arising, Bran would know it in time so that they be able to prepare and crush it. And he would not do it out of personal feelings, but because it is the truth, so people just have to nod. 

Tyrion did not choose a king who would reign; he choose an insurance policy. 

Basically, the Council just has to make choices and Bran says “yes” or “no”. This is basically what happens in the last episode: Bran leaves, the Council makes decisions. Because this is the thing with a King who feels nothing at all: most things are inconsequential and are not important in the great scheme of things. 

So Tyrion would make decisions, and expect Bran to tell him if his choices are bad. That’s all.

Of course, it’s a convenient system. People only have to do what the King tells them to do. Bran knows better after all, he is a godlike entity, isn’t he? We fall into a pattern of blind obedience. And Bran knows everything, which is just creepy and reminds me of the Patriot’s Act if you want my opinion. And finally – look at what Tyrion is doing in the final episode, chanting “All hail Bran the Broken” and everything. 

Blind obedience. Capacity to spy on everyone. Institutionalised devotion. Government composed of close friends, not competent people. 

Yeah, it makes me feel really uneasy. 

Actually, Tyrion acts just like Daenerys

It makes me even more uneasy when we know that Tyrion fell into that trap before with Daenerys (except that “capacity to spy on everyone” was replaced with “capacity to kill everyone”). 

This is why I am wary of Tyrion. He got rid of Jon, and I have difficulty believing that it was not intentional. And now, he’s setting up a government that looks pretty much tyrannical. 

The thing is, Tyrion acts very much like Dany, and that’s why I believe he loved her, as he told Jon. 

Tyrion also confesses that he hasn’t had sex in a while, ever since Shae. And this is the thing. He has not been interested by women ever since Shae - or even since Daenerys. The two event pretty much occur at the same time, actually. And remember Tyrion’s face during Jon and Dany’s boatbang? Yeah. It was jealousy.

Tyrion tries to prevent that from happening by sending Jaime to Cersei, but actually, if he really wanted to prevent it, the real solution was to kill Dany or support Jon’s claim, or at least let Varys do his business. Tyrion could just turn a blind eye and let things happen. No one would have resented him.

The thing is that Tyrion still wanted to be by Dany’s side. His aim was to prevent her from burning King’s Landing, but he knew, he had to know, that she would burn other cities. Then, of course, Tyrion’s reasoning is that Bran would be a good King because he’s neutral and would only do what is necessary for the realm - except that, of course, a neutral king who feels nothing is not a good idea. An emotionless king also means a king who does not feel pity or compassion. An emotionless king means a king who would plan everything according to a higher purpose, which would likely lead to neglecting everything that has nothing to do with the Great Purpose that only him could see - for example, the smallfolk. What is a few starved people compared to ensuring peace? 

So why would Tyrion choose Bran at all? My opinion is that, since Bran knows everything, Tyrion thinks he is the best safety system that could ever be. If the Small Council were to make a bad decision, Bran would know it and would stop it. If a rebellion or a war was arising, Bran would know it in time so that they be able to prepare and crush it. And he would not do it out of personal feelings, but because it is the truth, so people just have to nod. 

Tyrion did not choose a king who would reign; he choose an insurance policy. 

Basically, the Council just has to make choices and Bran says “yes” or “no”. This is basically what happens in the last episode: Bran leaves, the Council makes decisions. Because this is the thing with a King who feels nothing at all: most things are inconsequential and are not important in the great scheme of things. 

So Tyrion would make decisions, and expect Bran to tell him if his choices are bad. That’s all.

Of course, it’s a convenient system. People only have to do what the King tells them to do. Bran knows better after all, he is a godlike entity, isn’t he? We fall into a pattern of blind obedience. And Bran knows everything, which is just creepy and reminds me of the Patriot’s Act if you want my opinion. And finally – look at what Tyrion is doing in the final episode, chanting “All hail Bran the Broken” and everything. 

Blind obedience. Capacity to spy on everyone. Institutionalised devotion. Government composed of close friends, not competent people. 

Yeah, it makes me feel really uneasy. 

Actually, Tyrion acts just like Daenerys

It makes me even more uneasy when we know that Tyrion fell into that trap before with Daenerys (except that “capacity to spy on everyone” was replaced with “capacity to kill everyone”). 

This is why I am wary of Tyrion. He got rid of Jon, and I have difficulty believing that it was not intentional. And now, he’s setting up a government that looks pretty much tyrannical. 

The thing is, Tyrion acts very much like Dany, and that’s why I believe he loved her, as he told Jon. 

Tyrion also confesses that he hasn’t had sex in a while, ever since Shae. And this is the thing. He has not been interested by women ever since Shae - or even since Daenerys. The two event pretty much occur at the same time, actually. And remember Tyrion’s face during Jon and Dany’s boatbang? Yeah. It was jealousy.

The thing was Tyrion admired Dany a lot. He agreed with almost everything she did, except for burning people. I think that’s where Tyrion draws the line: massacring civilians for the sake of it.

Tyrion denounced Varys for trying to kill Daenerys and for generally opposing her, while knowing full well that she would burn King’s Landing to the ground. Tyrion tries to prevent that from happening by sending Jaime to Cersei, but actually, if he really wanted to prevent it, the real solution was to kill Dany or support Jon’s claim, or at least let Varys do his business. Tyrion could just turn a blind eye and let things happen. No one would have resented him.

The thing is that Tyrion still wanted to be by Dany’s side. His aim was to prevent her from burning King’s Landing, but he knew, he had to know, that she would burn other cities. That it would not be the end of it. But even though he betrayed her, he did not ensure that she would never hurt anyone. For me, it shows that he was still willing to follow her. Granted, he would have tried, again and again, to prevent her from burning citizens, but he was still willing to be by her side. He knew that a massacre was coming and he still loved Daenerys. She had committed massacres already and he still supported her. 

In the last episode, he mentions that “she killed the bad guys and we cheered her for it”, but he never mentions how the bad guys might… not actually be bad guys, after all (if we think about the innocent masters or the Khals, who weren’t killed because of their way of life but because she wanted to take their place). He never mentions that her way of killing people was cruel even from the start. He agreed with it up until she began burning people he knew and loved. 

In the same way, he did not think she should just calm down and stop threatening people, he thought people should stop provoking her. He already knew what was likely to happen if people (let’s say, Sansa) kept doing so. He was uneasy with it. But he still supported Daenerys.

And why, would you say? Why would he draw the limit at “burning civilians” but not for the rest? Because Tyrion thought she was doing great with the rest. And we see that in his government, because it mimicks Daenerys’.

His government is composed of close friends that would not oppose him, or so he thinks; and it relies heavily on obedience. The economy is not important in the government; no one takes military decisions but the authority in place (Dany or Bran or Tyrion); a lot of attention is given to the personal guard, but not to the rest. No one is there to represent the law. Most locals or nobles are not represented. People who have done nothing to deserve their titles get high authority. And, even though he has seen first hand what happens when someone is given way too much authority, he still believes in a strong central government with no room for independence, just like Dany - because he has the Bran safety stamp, so no problem.

 Tyrion tries to impose a kind of personality cult around Bran that looks like the one around Dany - Bran is magical so he knows better; Bran’s decisions are to be met with blind agreement because, you know, he’s omniscient. Tyrion’s government relies heavily on magical powers that actually put civilians at great risk. Tyrion’s choice as king would most likely focus on the Great Scheme of Things and The Higher Purpose, just like Dany did - even if there is a high risk that things go downhill for the common people, just like with Dany. 

And Tyrion suffers from the same ambition than Dany. Tyrion loves power, we know that. And he seeks glory as well, thinking himself to be super important in the story when he’s not. And he’s just as self-righteous as Dany was. If you look at his time as Joffrey’s Hand, his decisions were to be respected and he was to have power because he was the one to deserve it, and because he knows better. (You know, he drinks and he knows things.) His choice of Bran as King is to be respected because he knows things and because he’s wise and whatever. He gets rid of Jon because “it’s the only thing to do, there’s no other choice” – and then he plots for another king that fits his personal criteria, which coincidentally happen to be a replica of Daenerys’ criteria. You know what it reminds me of? “You are not fit to rule. But I am.” You are not fit to make decisions and to choose a King, but I am.

This is why Tyrion was so blind to Dany’s cruelty, and why it became different for him when she burnt people he knew: because in the end, he would have done things like her. Tyrion has learnt nothing, even though he pretends he had. He keeps committing the same mistakes over and over again.

Of course, you would say, “But Bran knows everything and if he thought that Tyrion was a bad person he would not have taken the Throne or taken Tyrion as Hand” and, actually, I think that Bran had no way of knowing that. Bran sees things, he does not feel them. He does not read people’s minds. He does not know that Tyrion shares similarities with Dany.

Because yes, he does. 

The thing is that, just like Dany, I don’t think he is conscious of it. I don’t think he coldly thought “Let’s have Jon killed along with Dany, two birds with one stone, I need to get rid of Jon”. He did send him to his likely death, and was certain that he would prevent Jon from being King, but I don’t think it was the result of a coldblooded scheme to get rid of Jon. I think that Tyrion is like Dany in this respect. He thought it was necessary. He justified it by telling it was the only thing left to do. And after all, he ensured that Jon did not die, and Jon didn’t want that Throne anyway, did he? So, no harm done. 

I am sure this is Tyrion’s reasoning. He chooses Bran because he thinks it’s the best choice. He handles his government in a certain way because he’s certain that this is the best thing to do. Because just like Daenerys, he’s proud and he thinks he’s always right. And just like Daenerys, he has a way to seduce people into, if not following him, at least listening to him. 

And if people agree with him then he’s doing things right, isn’t he?

Conclusion - Tyrion has the potential to be your everyday villain, just like Dany

I don’t think Tyrion was smiling in a satisfied, evil way and rubbing his hands together because everything went according to plan. He is exactly the type of villain that Dany was. The type that people (both in the show and in the audience) can like, the type that is relatable. The type that does not do bad things because he’s evil but because he thinks it’s the only way and because it’s the right thing to do. The type that does not realise that he’s doing bad things; and when he does, he thinks he has to do so nevertheless for “the greater good”. He is just like Dany. 

Of course, Tyrion will not end up burning cities to the ground. No, I see him making decisions that might have disastrous consequences - starvation, revolts, wars, things like that. If we’re lucky, maybe Bran will be able to prevent it from happening. I think maybe Tyrion will not even commit such mistakes. 

But he has the potential to commit them, because he makes horrible decisions that he feels are justified (like sending Jon to his own death), because he always turns things to his own advantage, because he likes power, because he reproduces a tyrannical system, because he does not realise it, because he has fallen in the same trap than Dany - that is, thinking that he is the hero. 

And the worst thing is that, if you want my opinion, D&D did not realise what they might have done with Tyrion’s character. They were blind to Dany’s cruelties in the past. She was their heroine up until GRRM said “hell no, she’s the bad one”. D&D reproduced the same system all over again without even seeing what they did. 

Of course, this is only my interpretation (and it might be heavily influenced by my own dislike of Tyrion after Season 8, or by the awful writing). I am open to any comment and/or constructive criticism. But I’m pretty sure that Tyrion is much more dangerous than we thought.
trail.content_abstract:
I’ve just realised something about Tyrion – and mind you, it doesn’t look good at all.

I was revolted (and I still am) by Tyrion’s attitude in the last episodes, especially the fact that he denounced Varys, which led to his inevitable demise, even though Tyrion knew that Varys was right, that Daenerys was dangerous and that she would burn King’s Landing to the ground.

I was also angry at him for basically doing nothing in the last episode. He acted like a drama queen by throwing his badge away and then encouraged Jon to kill Dany, while he could have kept the badge and done something. Tried to kill Dany himself. Hatched a plan. Actively conspired with Jon. Or even try to kill Dany and, if he failed, make Jon look like Dany’s most loyal supporter so that Dany would not suspect a thing – which is a dumb plan but at least Tyrion would have done something. 

But then I thought about something.

summary: probably the deepest asoiaf-related need i have right now is to understand how exactly jon, my sweet boy, got to the point where...
body:
probably the deepest asoiaf-related need i have right now is to understand how exactly jon, my sweet boy, got to the point where he could murder dany, my sweet (but problematic) girl, in cold blood. because i KNOW that is happening in canon– i don’t consider the show to be canon, but there’s no way d&d would have changed or created a major event like that without referring to what grrm told them of his ending in the books. 

sorry everyone– dany is probably dying at jon’s hand in the books too.

summary:
Jonerys Week
Re-sharing this for Missing Moments
Rating: Mature
Jon Snow/Daenerys Targaryen 
It was her favorite sound in the...
body:
Jonerys Week

Re-sharing this for Missing Moments

Illegitimi Non Carborundum - Reddragon1995 - Game of Thrones (TV) [Archive of Our Own]

Rating: Mature

Jon Snow/Daenerys Targaryen

It was her favorite sound in the world, his heartbeat thumping steady against her ear as her head rested on his scarred chest. Usually it was in the comfort of a bed, but the need for discretion demanded improvisation at the moment, with so many disapproving Northern eyes boring holes into her since she rode through the gates of her lover’s home. They could not afford to show too much affection or anything but a professional distance, lest his people accuse him of betraying his duty for lust.

It didn’t help matters that Jon Snow wasn’t the quickest with words. His political instincts were sharp in their way, but he was no orator. He simply didn’t have the patience to lecture his people, that they may appreciate the larger picture. He’d kept his temper, for the most part, though when she sat at his side at the high table and her blood ran as hot as his did with every disrespectful remark from a little girl and his haughty sister, she realized it took every ounce of his restraint not to overturn that table and silence those short sighted ingrates once and for all. Had she been more like her father, or even Viserys, she’d have had their tongues. The dark thought did cross her mind in a flash, but she chastised herself and maintained her composure. It didn’t mean she’d forgotten, though. She’d made a note that she would speak to Lady Mormont privately. Ser Jorah’s whelp of a distant cousin, who’d likely not even had her first blood, obviously fancied herself wise to the ways of politics and war. In other circumstances it may have been amusing. But not today.

Daenerys had not expected a warm reception. Jon, Lord Tyrion, and Jorah all had warned her that Northerners were mistrustful by nature. Loyal to their own, as Jon had put it. Only, he was one of their own, and from her perspective earlier, they didn’t seem particularly loyal to him. Dany learned long ago that people are loyal when loyalty suits them. If only these fools realized what suited them now, and it wasn’t their grumbling and murmuring and threatening to abandon their liege. He’d give up everything for them, and had, more than once.

Pricks , she thought.

summary: i think i have always been a jon hater
body:
i think i have always been a jon hater

so when jon was like “do you have faith in me at all?”

It was because of his decision in believing that dany, a person whom he met a month ago and a ruler of a castle with not a person from westeros but tyrion, varys and jorah and with foreigners in it..

it wasnt about the whole pol!jon theory, he’s really dumb isn’t he. He bent the knee without seeing firsthand of how this lady rules, he really gave the north to her.

summary: So What Now? - Doxa1 - Game of Thrones (TV) [Archive of Our Own]
title: So What Now? - Doxa1 - Game of Thrones (TV) [Archive of Our Own]
excerpt: An Archive of Our Own, a project of the Organization for Transformative Works
description:
Chapters: 14/?
Fandom: Game of Thrones (TV), A Song of Ice and Fire - George R. R. Martin
Rating: Mature
Warnings: Graphic Depictions Of Violence, Major Character Death
Relationships: Jon Snow/Daenerys Targaryen, Gilly (ASoIaF)/Samwell Tarly, Aegon VI Targaryen/Daenerys Targaryen
Characters: Jon Snow, Daenerys Targaryen, Aegon VI Targaryen, Tyrion Lannister, Davos Seaworth, Bran Stark, Yara Greyjoy, Kinvara (Game of Thrones), Daario Naharis, Bronn (ASoIaF), Podrick Payne, Brienne of Tarth, Gendry Waters
Additional Tags: Children, Post-Canon, Hurt/Comfort, Angst, Trauma, Intimacy, Original Character(s), Post-Canon Fix-It
Summary:

This is a post 8x06 fictional work that explores certain loose ends that weren’t tied. Daenerys is brought back to life. She’s a mother. Jon is on the other side of the continent. Back where they both started. It’s a slow burn story, but it won’t crawl (I promise).

blog.name: the-girl-in-the-high-castle
blog.title: Lot's Wife
blog.description: 24. Anthropologist. I want to meet someone that makes me feel the way music does. History nerd and eternaly suffering from Anemoia. I sold my soul to The Man In The High Castle, Brian Fallon, Brandon Flowers and Tom Smith. Eternal love for Babylon Berlin and Halt and Catch Fire. Always in discussion mod for A Song of Ice and Fire and The Wheel of Time.                                                                             "I've always dreamed of classic cars and movie screens."
